etymologies: late 16th century (denoting the division of one syllable into two): via Latin from Greek diairesis ‘separation’, from diairein ‘take apart’, from dia ‘apart’ + hairein ‘take’

definitions: a mark (¨) placed over a vowel to indicate that it is sounded in a separate syllable, as in naïve, Brontë.
shortDefinitions: mark (¨) placed over vowel to indicate that it is sounded separately, as in naïve

definitions: the division of a sound into two syllables, especially by sounding a diphthong as two vowels.
shortDefinitions: division of sound into two syllables

definitions: a natural rhythmic break in a line of verse where the end of a metrical foot coincides with the end of a word.
shortDefinitions: natural rhythmic break in line of verse where end of metrical foot coincides with end of phrase
